ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.2.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six grew their hair long.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.1_0: On one occasion in Rājagaha there was a hilltop fair,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.2_0: and the monks from the group of six went to see it.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.3_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.4_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics go to see dancing, singing, and music? They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.6_0: “You should not go to see dancing, singing, and the playing of music.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six were traveling with a drawn sword.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.2_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.3_0: “These Sakyan ascetics sing just like we do.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.4_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.5_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.6_0: “How can the monks from the group of six sing like this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.9_0: “It’s true, Sir.” ... and the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.10_0: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.11_0: “There are these five dangers in reciting the Teaching by singing in a drawn-out fashion:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.12_0: one delights in the sound; others delight in the sound; householders criticize it; for one who takes pleasure in the melody, the concentration is disrupted; later generations follow one’s example.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.13_0: These are the five drawbacks in reciting with a drawn-out singing sound.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.14_0: The teaching should not be singing.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.15_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.2.1_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not chant.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:4.1.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six wore fleecy woolen robes with the fleece on the outside.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:4.1.2_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:4.1.3_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd15:4.1.5_0: “You should not wear your chest wrapping clothes.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:4.1.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.1_0: On one occasion when the mango trees in King Bimbisāra’s park were bearing fruit,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.3_0: to eat as many mangoes as they wished.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.4_0: The monks from the group of six plucked and ate them all, even the young ones.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.5_0: Just then the King needed mangoes.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.7_0: “Go to the park and bring back mangoes.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.8_0: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” they did just that.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.9_0: “The King needs mangoes. Please get some.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.11_0: The monks plucked and ate them all, including the young ones.”

ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.13_0: “It’s good that the venerables have eaten the mangoes. Still, the Buddha has praised moderation.”

ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.16_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people

ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.2.6_0: Soon afterwards a certain association was offering a meal to the Sangha.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.1_0: On one occasion a monk had been bitten by a snake and died.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.3_0: “That monk had not radiated good will to the four royal snake clans.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.4_0: Had he done so, he would not have died.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.6_0: The Virūpakkhas, the Erāpathas, the Chabyāputtas, and the Kaṇhāgotamas.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.7_0: Because that mendicant mustn’t have spread a mind of love to the four royal snake families.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.8_0: Had he done so, he would not have died.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.9_0: To protect yourselves, monks, you should spread good will to these four royal snake clans.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.10_0: And this is how it should be done.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.13_0: I have good will toward the Chabyāputtas,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.15_0: I have good will toward the legless,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.16_0: Toward the two-legged I have good will;
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.17_0: I have good will toward the four-legged,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.19_0: May the footless not harm me!
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.20_0: May the two-legged not hurt me.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.21_0: May the four-legged not hurt me,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.22_0: May the many-legged not hurt me.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.23_0: All sentient beings, all living things,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.25_0: may they see only nice things,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.26_0: May none meet with anything bad.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.35_0: And so I revere the Blessed One,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.36_0: I revere the seven perfectly awakened Buddhas.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:7.1.1_0: At one time a monk who was plagued by discontent some people cut down his own penis.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:7.1.3_0: “This fool has cut off one thing, when he should have cut off something else.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:7.1.4_0: You should not cut off your own penis.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:7.1.5_0: If you do, you commit a serious offense.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.1_0: On one occasion a prominent merchant of Rājagaha had obtained a very valuable block of sandalwood.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.3_0: “I will have a bowl carved from this block of sandal.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.4_0: I’ll use the chips myself, but give the bowl away as a gift.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.5_0: He then had a bowl carved, put it in a carrying net, hung it at the end of a succession of vertical bamboo poles, and announced,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.6_0: “I will give this bowl to any perfected ascetic or brahmin who brings it down by supernormal powers.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.7_0: Pūraṇa Kassapa went to that merchant and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.8_0: “I’m perfected and have supernormal powers. Give me the bowl.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.9_0: “If you’re perfected and have supernormal powers, then bring it down and it’s yours.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.10_0: The same thing happened with Makkhali Gosāla,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.14_0: Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta went to Rājagaha and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.15_0: “I’m perfected and have supernormal powers. Give me the bowl.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.16_0: “If you’re perfected and have supernormal powers, then bring it down and it’s yours.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.17_0: Soon afterwards, after robing up in the morning, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna and Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja took their bowls and robes and entered Rājagaha for alms.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.19_0: “Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, you have supernormal powers and psychic powers.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.22_0: “Venerable Bhāradvāja, the perfected ones and those supernormal powers
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.25_0: Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja then rose up in the air, took hold of that bowl, and circled around Rājagaha three times.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.26_0: Just then that merchant together with his wives and children was standing in his own house with joined palms raised in homage, thinking,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.27_0: “May Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja land right here at our house.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.28_0: And Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja did just that.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.29_0: The merchant then took the bowl from his hands, filled it with expensive non-staple food, and gave it back to Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.30_0: who then left for the monastery.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.1_0: Hearing that the Buddha had allowed dwellings,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.2_0: that Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja had taken down the merchant’s bowl,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.3_0: and making a great uproar, they followed right behind him.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.5_0: He asked Venerable Ānanda what was going on,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.6_0: “Ānanda, why is there this loud sound of recitation?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.7_0: and Ānanda explained to him all that had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.8_0: Hearing that the Buddha had allowed dwellings,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.9_0: that Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja had taken down the merchant’s bowl,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.10_0: and making a great uproar, they followed right behind him.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.12_0: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha of monks gathered and questioned Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.13_0: “Is it true, Bhāradvāja, that you have the merchant’s bowl?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.16_0: “It’s not suitable, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.17_0: How can you show a superhuman ability, a wonder of supernormal power, to householders for the sake of a miserable wooden bowl?
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.18_0: Suppose there was a female shop with a female scoundrel. Whereas, when six years have passed,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.19_0: In the same way, you show a superhuman ability, a wonder of supernormal power, to householders for the sake of a miserable wooden bowl.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.20_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.22_0: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.23_0: “You should not show a superhuman ability, a wonder of supernormal power, to householders.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.24_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.25_0: Now destroy that wooden bowl and make it into splinters. Give these to the monks to use as scent in ointment.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.26_0: And you should not use a wooden bowl.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.27_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six used luxurious bowls made with gold and silver.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.2_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.3_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.5_0: “You should not use a golden bowl. ...
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.7_0: should not wear a bowl of buttermilk,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.9_0: should not wear a bench made with fruit,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.11_0: should not wear a bowl shop,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.12_0: or a bowlful of three bowlfuls,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.13_0: should not wear a bowl bag ...
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.15_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:9.1.16_0: I allow two kinds of almsbowl:

ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.1_0: At one time Vaḍḍha the Licchavī was a friend of the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.2_0: On one occasion he approached them and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.4_0: When they said this, the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka were not able to respond.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.7_0: but they still did not respond.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.8_0: and a third time he said the same thing,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.10_0: but they still did not respond.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.11_0: “Have I done something wrong? Why don’t you respond?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.12_0: “It’s because we’ve been treated badly by Dabba the Mallian and you’re not taking an interest.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.14_0: “If you like, you could make the Buddha expel Dabba.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.15_0: “What should I do? How am I able to do that?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.17_0: ‘Venerable Sir, this isn’t proper or appropriate.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.18_0: There’s fear, distress, and oppression in this district, where none of these should exist.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.20_0: It seems to me that water is burning,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.1.21_0: Venerable Dabba the Mallian has raped my wife.’”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.1_0: Saying, “Yes,” he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.3_0: what he had been told to say.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.4_0: There’s fear, distress, and oppression in this district, where none of these should exist.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.6_0: It seems to me that water is burning,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.7_0: Venerable Dabba the Mallian has raped my wife.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.8_0: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned Dabba:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.9_0: “Dabba, do you remember doing as these things?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.12_0: and a third time the Buddha asked
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.13_0: “Dabba, do you remember doing as these things?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.15_0: He then said, “Dabba, the Dabbas don’t give such evasive answers.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.16_0: If it was done by you, say so;
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.17_0: if it wasn’t done by you, then say that.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.2.18_0: “Sir, since I was born I don’t recall having sexual intercourse even in a dream, much less when awake.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.3.1_0: The Buddha said to the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.3.2_0: “Well then, monks, the Sangha should overturn the almsbowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.3.3_0: When a lay follower has eight qualities, you should overturn your bowl against him:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.3.4_0: They try to prevent the mendicants from getting material possessions. They try to harm mendicants. They try to drive mendicants from a monastery. They insult and abuse mendicants. They divide mendicants against each other. They criticize the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.3.5_0: “Monks, I allow you to overturn the bowl against a lay follower who has these eight qualities.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.1_0: And the overturning of the bowl is to be done like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.2_0: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.3_0: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.4_0: Dabba the Mallian groundlessly charged Venerable Dabba with failure in morality.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.5_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should overturn the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.7_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.8_0: Dabba the Mallian groundlessly charged Venerable Dabba with failure in morality.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.9_0: The Sangha overturns the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.10_0: Any monk who approves of designating Vaḍḍha the Licchavī should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.11_0: Any monk who doesn’t agree should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.12_0: The Sangha has overturned the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.4.13_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.1_0: After robing up the following morning, Venerable Ānanda took his bowl and robe, went to the house of Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, and told him,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.2_0: “Vaḍḍha, the Sangha has overturned the bowl against you.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.3_0: You’re prohibited from interacting with the Sangha.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.5_0: The Sangha has overturned my bowl against me, it seems, placed me in the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.7_0: But Vaḍḍha’s friends and relatives said to him,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.9_0: We’ll reconcile you with the Buddha and the Sangha of monks.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.10_0: At this time Vaḍḍha, the Licchavī, Posaṇḍa, and the Visākha approached the Buddha, and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.11_0: “Sir, I’ve committed an offense. Foolishly, deludedly, and unskillfully I acted like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.12_0: Please accept my confession for my future restraint.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.13_0: “Certainly you have committed an offense. Foolishly, deludedly, and unskillfully you acted like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.14_0: But since you acknowledge your offense and you make amends for it in accordance with the Teaching, I accept your confession.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.15_0: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.6.1_0: The Buddha said to the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.6.2_0: “Well then, the Sangha should turn the almsbowl upright for Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, allowing him to interact with the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.6.3_0: When a lay follower has eight qualities, you should turn your bowl upright for him:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.6.4_0: he is not trying to stop monks from acquiring material gains; he is not trying to harm monks; he is not trying to get monks to lose their place of residence; he doesn’t abuse or revile monks; he doesn’t cause division between monks; he doesn’t disparage the Buddha; he doesn’t disparage the Teaching; he doesn’t disparage the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.6.5_0: “Monks, I allow you to turn your bowl upright for lay followers.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.1_0: And it should be done like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.2_0: Vaḍḍha the Licchavī should approach the Sangha, put his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the monks, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.3_0: ‘Venerable Sir, the Sangha has overturned the bowl against me. I haven’t prohibited from interacting with the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.4_0: I have conducted myself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released. I ask the Sangha for the full ordination.’

ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.9_0: The Sangha has overturned the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.10_0: He has conducted himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.11_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should turn the bowl upright for Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, allowing him to interact with the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.13_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.14_0: The Sangha has overturned the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.15_0: He has conducted himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.17_0: Any monk who approves of turning the bowl upright for Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, allowing him to interact with the Sangha should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.18_0: Any monk who doesn’t agree should speak up.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.1_0: When the Buddha had stayed at Vesālī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward the country of Bhaggā.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.3_0: he stayed at Susumāragira in the Bhesakaḷā Grove, the deer park.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.4_0: At this time Prince Bodhi had recently built the Kokanada stilt house. It had not yet been inhabited by any ascetic or brahmin, or anyone else.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.5_0: The Prince said to the young brahmin Sañcikāputta,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.6_0: “My dear Sañcikāputta, please go to the Buddha, bow down in my name with your head at his feet,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.7_0: and ask whether he is free from sickness, free from illness, in good health, and living comfortably, (and say):
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.8_0: if he is healthy, strong, and living at ease.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.10_0: might accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the mendicant Saṅgha.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.11_0: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” Sañcikāputta went to the Buddha and exchanged pleasantries with him. He then sat down
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.12_0: and told the Buddha all he had been asked to say,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.13_0: “Prince Bodhi, dear Gotama, worships with his head at ease.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.15_0: concluding with the invitation for the meal on the following day.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.16_0: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.1_0: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Sañcikāputta got up from his seat, returned to the Prince, and told him what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.2_0: “I gave the ascetic Gotama your message,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.3_0: if he is healthy, strong, and living at ease.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.5_0: together with the mendicant Saṅgha, might please accept tomorrow’s meal from Prince Bodhi.’
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.7_0: The next morning Prince Bodhi had various kinds of fine food prepared, and had the entire Kokanada stilt house covered with white cloth, all the way to the bottom step of the staircase. He then said to Sañcikāputta,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.8_0: “My dear Sañcikāputta, please go to the Buddha and inform him,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.9_0: and tell him the meal is ready.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.11_0: saying: “It is time, dear Gotama, the meal is ready.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.12_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Prince Bodhi’s home.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.13_0: Now at that time Prince Bodhi was standing outside the gates waiting for the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.14_0: When he saw the Buddha coming,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.15_0: he went out to meet him, bowed down to him, and went to the Kokanada stilt house with the Buddha in front.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.16_0: But the Buddha stopped at the bottom stair of that staircase.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.18_0: “Sir, please step on the cloth. It will be for my longterm benefit and happiness.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.19_0: When this was said, the Fortunate One remained silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.22_0: “Sir, please step on the cloth. It will be for my longterm benefit and happiness.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.23_0: Then the Fortunate One looked at venerable Ānanda.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.24_0: And Ānanda said to the Prince,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.26_0: The Buddha doesn’t step on cloth coverings. The Buddha has compassion for later generations.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.1_0: So Prince Bodhi had the cloth folded up and the seats spread out upstairs in the longhouse.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.2_0: Then the Buddha ascended the longhouse and sat on the seats spread out together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.3_0: The Prince personally served the various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal and had washed his hands and bowl, the Prince sat down to one side.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.4_0: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching, after which he got up from his seat and left.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.5_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.6_0: “You should not step on a cloth covering.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.1_0: On one occasion a woman who was unable to conceive invited the monks, prepared a cloth, and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.3_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not step them.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.4_0: “Please step on the cloth as a blessing.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.6_0: That woman complained and criticized them,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.7_0: “How can the venerables, when asked, not step on a cloth as a blessing?”

ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.11_0: I allow you, when asked, to step on a cloth covering as a blessing for householders.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.12_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not step on a sheet after washing their feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.14_0: “I allow you to step on a sheet after washing your feet.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.15_0: The second recitation section is finished.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.1.1_0: On one occasion the Sangha was given a mosquito whisk.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.1_0: On one occasion the Sangha was given a sunshade.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.4_0: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six walked about holding a sunshade.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.5_0: When a certain Buddhist lay follower and a number of Ājīvaka followers went to a park,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.6_0: they saw the group of six monks with their sunshades.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.7_0: They said to that lay follower,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.8_0: “These venerables of yours are coming. They are holding sunshades, just like accountants and government officials.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.9_0: “These are not monks; they are wanderers.”

ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.18_0: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.20_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.4.5_0: “I allow you to use a sunshade in a monastery and in the vicinity of a monastery, even if you’re healthy.”
